title: Burundi's full independence from Belgium is achieved
The United States recognizes the new Cuban government of Fidel Castro
Morocco formally achieves its full independence from France
Elizabeth II becomes Queen of the United Kingdom and other Commonwealth realms
Willard Libby develops radiocarbon dating, a process that revolutionizes archaeology and paleontology
World War II, the deadliest conflict in history, comes to an end
Animated musical film "Fantasia" is produced and released by Walt Disney Productions
Belgian surrealist René Magritte paints "Time Transfixed"
Picasso's prominent work "Guernica" is painted and exhibited at the Paris International Exposition
Salvador Dalí paints "The Persistence of Memory"
Maurice Ravel composes his most famous work, "Boléro"
The Stockholm Public Library designed by Gunnar Asplund is officially opened
"Rhapsody in Blue" by George Gershwin premieres at Aeolian Hall, Manhattan
Famed Italian opera composer Giacomo Puccini dies in Brussels aged 65
Naturalised American science fiction writer Isaac Asimov is born in Petrovichi, Russia
The controversial film "The Birth of a Nation", directed by D. W. Griffith, premieres in Los Angeles
Marie Curie wins the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for her discovery of the elements polonium and radium
Marianne von Werefkin paints "Tragic Atmosphere"
Einstein publishes the annus mirabilis papers, major contributions to the foundation of modern physics
The film "A Trip to the Moon" by French filmmaker Georges Méliès is released
Nobel Prizes are awarded for the first time
"La bohème" by Giacomo Puccini premieres in Turin
The island of Taiwan, together with the Penghu Islands, becomes a dependency of Japan
New Zealand is the first country in the world to give women the right to vote in parliamentary elections
"Gösta Berling's Saga", debut novel of Swedish author Selma Lagerlöf, is published
Piano compositions "Gymnopédies" are written by French composer and pianist Erik Satie
Édouard Manet finishes his painting "Un bar aux Folies Bergère"
"A Doll's House", a three-act play by Norwegian playwright Henrik Ibsen, premieres in Copenhagen, Denmark
Jules Verne's "Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Seas" is published in book form
The Quebec Conference is held to discuss a proposed Canadian confederation
Volume "Les Fleurs du mal" by French poet Charles Baudelaire is first published
"Moby-Dick" by American writer Herman Melville is first published
English author Emily Brontë publishes "Wuthering Heights" under her pen name Ellis Bell
Norwegian composer and pianist Edvard Grieg is born in Bergen
Two versions of the subject "The Burning of the Houses of Lords and Commons" are painted by William Turner
Japanese ukiyo-e artist Hokusai creates his notorious woodblock print "The Great Wave off Kanagawa"
Declaration of independence of Brazil from Portugal
German artist Caspar David Friedrich paints his "Wanderer above the Sea of Fog"
Mary Shelley publishes her iconic novel "Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus"
Birth of Ada Lovelace, mathematician and writer, often referred to as the first computer programmer
"Pride and Prejudice" by English author Jane Austen is published in Whitehall, London
Antonio Canova finishes sculpting "Pauline Bonaparte as Venus Victrix"
The renowned Père Lachaise Cemetery is established in Paris
First edition of "Lyrical Ballads" by the English poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart composes "The Marriage of Figaro"
German philosopher Immanuel Kant publishes his "Critique of Pure Reason"
United States Declaration of Independence is adopted in Philadelphia
Novel "A Sentimental Journey Through France and Italy" is written and published by Laurence Sterne
Johann Winckelmann publishes his "Geschichte der Kunst des Alterthums" ("The History of Art in Antiquity")
English fine china, porcelain and luxury accessories manufacturer Wedgwood is founded
Venetian painter Rosalba Carriera known for her pastel portraits dies aged 84
The suite in D major for wind instruments "Music for the Royal Fireworks" is composed by George F. Handel
The Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle (Aachen) ends the War of the Austrian Succession
The Anglo-Irish writer and clergyman Jonathan Swift publishes "Gulliver's Travels"
Philosopher, historian, economist, librarian and essayist David Hume is born in Edinburgh, Scotland
Thomas Savery develops the first commercial steam-powered device: a water pump
Isaac Newton publishes the "Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica"
The Ottoman Empire is defeated in the second Siege of Vienna
China conquers the Kingdom of Tungning and annexes Taiwan
The Great Fire of London takes place
Masterpiece "Girl with a Pearl Earring" by Dutch painter Jan Vermeer
Diego Velázquez paints his world-renowned masterpiece "Las Meninas"
The Taj Mahal, a mausoleum on the right bank of the river Yamuna in Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India, is completed
"The Night Watch", one of the most famous Dutch Golden Age paintings, is completed by Rembrandt van Rijn
The "Discourse on the Method" by René Descartes is published in Leiden, in the Netherlands
"Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems" by astronomer, physicist and engineer Galileo Galilei
Tragedy "Macbeth" by William Shakespeare is first performed
Rialto Bridge in Venice, designed by Antonio da Ponte, is completed
The Treaty of Constantinople is signed between the Ottoman Empire (Turkey) and the Safavid Empire (Iran)
The Gregorian calendar, used in most parts of the world, goes into effect
Death of Suleiman the Magnificent, the longest-reigning sultan of the Ottoman Empire
The Battle of Djerba takes place near the island of Djerba, Tunisia, resulting in an Ottoman victory
Elizabeth I, the last monarch of the House of Tudor, becomes Queen of England and Ireland at the age of 25
Michelangelo finishes painting his masterpiece fresco "The Last Judgment" in the Sistine Chapel
Coronation of Charles V as Holy Roman Emperor (last emperor to receive a papal coronation)
Siege of Vienna, first attempt by the Ottoman Empire to capture the capital of the Holy Roman Empire
Martin Luther writes his Ninety-five Theses giving origin to Protestantism
Albrecht Dürer paints his Self-Portrait, or Self-Portrait at Twenty-Eight
